verses.text: Let God arise, let His enemies be scattered; let those who hate Him flee before Him.
verses.comment: Echoes Moses’ words in Num. 10:35 as the Ark sets out, symbolizing God going before His people in power. Note: In Catholic liturgy, this verse is used for Easter procession, signifying Christ’s victory over death.

verses.text: As smoke is driven away, so You drive them away; as wax melts before fire, so the wicked perish before God.
verses.comment: The imagery emphasizes the total destruction of sin before God's holiness. Catholics see this as a reminder of divine justice and purification, which is also liturgically referenced during exorcisms.

verses.text: But the righteous rejoice; they exalt before God, they are glad and rejoice.
verses.comment: Righteousness leads to true joy in God. The Catholic tradition emphasizes this joy is expressed perfectly in the saints and Marian devotion.

verses.text: Sing to God, sing praises to His name; exalt Him who rides on the clouds; His name is the LORD; rejoice before Him!
verses.comment: ‘Rides on the clouds’ invokes divine kingship—fulfilled in Christ’s Ascension (Acts 1:9). ‘His name is the LORD’ (“Yahweh”); the Catholic faith preserves reverence for the Divine Name in liturgy.

verses.text: Father of the fatherless and protector of widows is God in His holy dwelling.
verses.comment: Shows God’s concern for the marginalized—a theme also seen in James 1:27. Catholics express this universally through the Church’s social teaching and charitable works.

verses.text: God settles the lonely in families; He leads out the prisoners with singing, but the rebellious dwell in a dry land.
verses.comment: Liberation and inclusion—foreshadowing Christ freeing captives (Luke 4:18). 'Families' point to the importance of the faith community, a strong teaching in Catholic ecclesiology.

verses.text: O God, when You went out before Your people, when You marched through the wilderness, Selah
verses.comment: 'Selah' indicates a pause for reflection. God’s guiding presence in the Exodus is recounted here; in Catholic tradition, such journeys are seen as prefigurations of spiritual pilgrimage.

verses.text: The earth quaked, the heavens poured down rain at the presence of God, even Sinai itself quaked before God, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: References Mount Sinai and divine revelation. Catholics revere God’s manifest presence especially as fulfilled in the Sacraments.

verses.text: You sent forth abundant rain, O God; You restored Your inheritance when it was weary.
verses.comment: Physical rain is also symbolic of the Holy Spirit’s outpouring—fulfilled at Pentecost (Acts 2:1-4). Catholic tradition emphasizes spiritual renewal through sacraments.

verses.text: Your flock settled in it; in Your goodness, O God, You provided for the poor.
verses.comment: 'Your flock' is the people of God—a term later used for the Church. Catholic ecclesiology sees the Church as God’s flock, providing spiritual and material needs.

verses.text: The Lord gives the word; the women who announce the good news are a great host:
verses.comment: Women play significant roles in announcing God’s victories—foreshadowing Mary Magdalene and others at the Resurrection (John 20:18), an honor upheld in Catholic tradition.

verses.text: ‘The kings of armies—they flee, they flee!’ And she who stays at home divides the spoil.
verses.comment: Victory is complete; even those not in battle share in its fruits. Catholic teaching emphasizes the communion of saints—all benefit in Christ’s victory.

verses.text: Though you lie among the sheepfolds, the wings of a dove covered with silver, its pinions with shimmering gold.
verses.comment: Images of peace and opulence. The dove often symbolizes the Holy Spirit, and this verse is used in Catholic iconography for the Church’s spiritual riches.

verses.text: When the Almighty scattered kings there, it was snowing on Zalmon.
verses.comment: God’s intervention is swift and unmistakable, changing the landscape. The Church teaches that God’s providence can transform all situations.

verses.text: Mount Bashan is a mighty mountain, a mountain of many peaks is Mount Bashan.
verses.comment: Refers to impressive mountains, but God’s chosen mountain—Zion—has greater significance; Catholic tradition sees Zion as a type of the Church.

verses.text: Why do you look with envy, you high mountains, at the mountain God desires for His dwelling? Yes, the LORD will dwell there forever.
verses.comment: God chooses Zion as His dwelling—key for Catholic teaching on God’s real presence in the Church and, notably, in the Eucharist.

verses.text: The chariots of God are twice ten thousand, thousands upon thousands; the Lord is among them; Sinai is now in the sanctuary.
verses.comment: Heavenly armies surround God. Catholics see this fulfilled in the Communion of Saints, angels present at the liturgy.

verses.text: You ascended on high, leading captives in Your train; You received gifts among men, even among the rebellious, that the LORD God may dwell there.
verses.comment: Quoted in Eph. 4:8 as prophecy of Christ’s Ascension. Catholics affirm this prefigures Christ bestowing spiritual gifts through the Church.

verses.text: Blessed be the Lord, who daily bears us up; God is our salvation. Selah
verses.comment: Daily help and salvation—echoed in Catholic prayer, such as the Divine Office, throughout the day.

verses.text: Our God is a God of deliverance, and to God, the Lord, belong escapes from death.
verses.comment: Deliverance from death points to Christ’s Resurrection, the foundation of the Catholic promise of eternal life.

verses.text: But God will shatter the head of His enemies, the hairy scalp of the one walking in guilt.
verses.comment: ‘Bruising the head’ recalls Gen. 3:15 and is spiritually interpreted as Christ’s victory over Satan—celebrated in Catholic liturgy on Easter Vigil.

verses.text: The Lord said, ‘I will bring them back from Bashan, I will bring them back from the depths of the sea,’
verses.comment: Recovery from danger or death is ultimately fulfilled in Christ rescuing souls—a doctrine central to Catholic understanding of redemption.

verses.text: That you may bathe your feet in blood, that the tongues of your dogs may have their share from the enemy.
verses.comment: Vivid image of victory—final judgment also has spiritual meaning: Catholic tradition emphasizes Christ’s triumph over sin and death.

verses.text: They have seen Your processions, O God, the processions of my God, my King, into the sanctuary.
verses.comment: Procession into the sanctuary prefigures liturgical processions in Catholic worship, particularly at Easter and Corpus Christi.

verses.text: The singers in front, the musicians last, between them maidens playing tambourines:
verses.comment: Levitical worship foreshadows the order and formality in Catholic liturgy—music, processions, and participation.

verses.text: Bless God in the congregation, the Lord, O you who are from the fountain of Israel!
verses.comment: Gathered worship is central; Catholic tradition sees this in the Mass, fulfilling ‘assembly’ (Heb. 10:25).

verses.text: There is Benjamin, the youngest, ruling them, the princes of Judah in their assembly, the princes of Zebulun, the princes of Naphtali.
verses.comment: Unity of Israel’s tribes; the Church sees itself as the new Israel, gathering all nations under Christ.

verses.text: Your God has ordained your strength; show Your power, O God, as You have worked for us before.
verses.comment: Recognition of God’s intervention. Catholics see God’s strength made perfect in sacramental grace and apostolic succession.

verses.text: Because of Your temple at Jerusalem kings shall bring gifts to You.
verses.comment: Gentile kings bringing gifts—fulfilled magi visiting Christ (Matt. 2:11), and in Catholic understanding, the Church as the new Temple draws all nations.

verses.text: Rebuke the beasts in the reeds, the herd of bulls with the calves of the peoples; trample down those who delight in silver; scatter the nations who desire war.
verses.comment: Metaphors for hostile nations. Catholic teaching urges peace, recalling Christ as the Prince of Peace.

verses.text: Nobles shall come from Egypt; Cush shall hasten to stretch out her hands to God.
verses.comment: Universal worship: Gentiles join in God’s praise. The Catholic Church sees this unity as a foretaste of heaven (Rev. 7:9).

verses.text: O kingdoms of the earth, sing to God; sing praises to the Lord, Selah
verses.comment: Missionary command—universal praise is foundational to Catholic teaching on evangelization.

verses.text: To Him who rides upon the highest heavens, which are from ancient times; behold, He utters His voice, a mighty voice.
verses.comment: 'His voice' recalls God’s Word; Catholic teaching sees Christ as the eternal Logos (John 1:1).

verses.text: Ascribe power to God, whose majesty is over Israel, and whose strength is in the skies.
verses.comment: Affirmation of God’s sovereignty is central; Catholics honor this in praise and solemn worship.

verses.text: Awesome is God in His sanctuary; the God of Israel gives power and strength to His people. Blessed be God!
verses.comment: ‘Sanctuary’ as God’s dwelling leads Catholics to connect this psalm with Christ’s presence in the Eucharist—the greatest gift and source of strength for the Church.
